text:
ORION CARRINGTON:
Welcome to Denver.

I'm Orion Carringinton,
Denver's go-to guy
when it comes to food.

I host a food show called
"Let's Eat" on Comcast,

so I know all the local hot
spots in the Mile High City.

This city has an
impressive culinary

scene, which is perfect for
me because I love to eat.

I'm going to take you to a few
places you need to check out
the next time you're in Denver.

Tucked away on the ground
floor of this 54 story

tower in downtown
Denver you'll find

Guard and Grace, a
modern steakhouse
with style and class.

This a great place
to entertain clients
or have a business meeting.

And in my opinion, it's
the best steak in town.

All right Troy, you guys
were voted best steakhouse
for the past three years.
What's your secret?

TROY GUARD: Our staff
here is dynamite.
ORION CARRINGTON: Yeah.

TROY GUARD: But the
secret is that grill
back there is oak fired grill.

So it flavors the
meat, the pork,

the seafood with this
nice charcoal oak flavor.

And you can see that
chardness done on it.

And it really, hands
down, sets us apart
from all the other steakhouses.

There's something
about a backyard

barbecue cooking
with charcoal or wood
that just has that flavor.

ORION CARRINGTON:
Just around the corner

from Denver's historic
Larimer Square is Euclid Hall.

Just like the city,
it's elegant and laid
back all at the same time.
The food here is amazing.

They have pub food
from around the world,
and an extensive beer menu.

Denver born chef Jorel Pierce
has been with Euclid Hall
since it opened.

JOREL PIERCE: When
we opened, we opened

to be a restaurant for
chefs and a restaurant

for you know, cooks and
restaurateurs and industry kids
to come after work.

Today we've got the staples
of Euclid Hall's menu,

the house made sausages
from all local pork
and beef, house made mustards.
We've got the marrow bones.

We've got the fowl
plate, it's kind
of a juiced up duck poutine.
ORION CARRINGTON: That's my jam.

JOREL PIERCE: Really, our
commitment is to a local farm

and representing food
the way it should be.

You know, trying to
make an immediate impact
on our food system.

ORION CARRINGTON:
Our last stop has

all the fun of going
to a food truck
without having to chase it down.
You're going to love this.

Denver's Avanti
Food and Beverage

packs seven restaurant concepts
into shipping container
kitchens all under one roof.
It's a modern day food court.

But instead of franchises,
it's local mom and pop shops.

BECKIE PANASEWICZ: Avanti is a
food and beverage collective.
It's a food incubator.

You automatically have a
leg up then if you were
just a small brick and mortar.

I don't know anywhere
else that you

can really get that quality
of food and that variety all
in one place.
It's a good place to grow.

ORION CARRINGTON:
It's two floors,

two bars, and restaurant
concepts that rotate over time.

KADE GIANINETTI: Denver
is the perfect place

to open a progressive
restaurant and have a chance
for it to be successful.

ORION CARRINGTON:
Thanks for joining me

in this fun foodie adventure
in the Mile High City.

Come on out and discover
your own favorite.

Just be careful, you
might not want to leave.
Cheers.
